projects.title: Research
projects.subtitle: What do we mean by research?

dynamic.text: We want to rethink our social interaction from a design practice perspective: an open-ended process allows us to question proven ways of communication and interaction and to develop new formats, design directions and methods. In addition to the design implementation, we develop the project idea, take over planning and strategy and carry out participative formats such as workshops. In doing so, it is important for us to leave our discipline completely and to create a joint process with other experts. By doing, we find solutions. For example, are you an entrepreneur looking for new forms of contact with your customers? Are you, as a municipality, trying to make a public space available for community use? Are you a scientist who wants to apply practical research methods? We are happy to provide creative impulses for your project and support you in redefining questions, advancing ideas and implementing changes. Contact us with your project ideas: info@basundaer.de

projects.title: Building Cultural Landscapes
projects.subtitle: Visual Essay for conference publication „STRING FIGURES – Transforming together“

dynamic.text: LESSONS WE LEARNT – VISUAL ESSAY TO ‘LAND IN SICHT’ As part of the ‘String Figures - Transforming Together’ conference at the University of Bolzano 2023, we were able to present and critically reflect on the experiences from the ‘Land in Sicht’ project to an expert audience. Everyone who initiates new projects can report on resistance and challenges. However, we also gain new insights through experimental and unfamiliar approaches. Our contribution focuses on the potential of fictional narratives from our project week and the lessons that can be learnt from them for the successful development of new cultural landscapes.

image.alt: Illustration of a futuristic village center

dynamic.text: At the centre of our investigation there are the results of the design fiction workshop conducted during the ‘Land in Sicht’ project (workshop facilitator G. Graf), in which the participants were asked to imagine a life as creative professionals in rural areas in the future. What kind of world would they find themselves in? What challenges and opportunities would there be for them? From the four fictional stories that emerged, we developed factors that are relevant to the success of transformation in cultural landscapes in the course of our research work.

gallery.alt: Illustration of a creatur that stick its head into a bubble

captions: Design Fiction Scenario: “The Underwater Air Camp”
Design Fiction Scenario: “The Artist and the Monk”

dynamic.text: From this Design Fiction narratives of the workshop four factors can be derived to effect the success of cultural transforamtion in rural (or any other) areas:

1. CULTURAL MEDIATOR
In transformative cultural projects, the involvement of a cultural mediator is essential. The person should be able to translate effectively between artists and local communities.
 In the design fiction scenario “The Underwater Air Camp”, a hybrid being, the ‘Humano-Marinaio-Didatico’, takes on this role. In the story, it mediates between a fictitious underwater colony and outsiders and responds sensitively to the expectations, needs and expressed values of both parties. This role model, the trust and empathy that goes with it creates a stable basis for fragile relationships in new types of cultural projects.

2. NEUTRAL AUDITOR
In contrast to the mediator, the person in this role is not involved in the project. He or she should be objective and impartial as well as have the necessary qualifications to challenge the established structures between artists and locals (society). The neutral auditor checks that the intended project runs smoothly and does not stray off course.
The scenario “The Artist and the Monk” from the design fiction workshop serves as a model for this role. It describes how the hustle and bustle of a village gets out of control due to crazy ideals and how this is only recognised by an impartial actor.

3. COMMON GROUND
In the “Modular Artist Residency” scenario, the (re)creation of shared values is at the centre of a completely new community. This is a decisive factor for lasting, site-specific transformations. In order to effectively build or revitalise a local community, mutual acceptance and the definition of commonalities are required.
 The introduction of a modular residency system for artists challenges conventional notions of living spaces and offers an inventive approach to cultivating a nomadic art community. This scenario encourages a rethinking of the boundaries between city and countryside.

4. MOMENTS OF INCUBATION
Initial interventions serve as ‘door openers’ (portals), which are often the starting point for unusual collaborations. The interest groups – artists and closed communities – can change perspectives here.
A vivid example of such an incubation moment could be the sound installation “Boule” by Janis E. Müller, which was shown during the opening of the ‘Land in Sicht’ exhibition in Ottobeuren. In the live sound installation, a set of boules balls invited visitors to play and thus participate in unconventional experiences with artistic practices. The accessible interaction generated a jubilant response, regardless of the cultural background of the guests.

gallery.alt: Illustration of a modular Artist Residence

captions: Design Fiction Scenario: “Modular Artist Residence”, Illustration: Vanessa Müller-Graf
Inspired by the sound performance: “Boule” of Janis E. Müller

dynamic.text: “Playing games of string figures is about giving and receiving patterns, dropping threads and failing but sometimes finding something that works, something consequential and maybe even beautiful, that wasn’t there before, of relaying connections that matter, of telling stories in hand upon hand, digit upon digit, attachment site upon attachment site, to craft conditions for finite flourishing on terra, on earth.” – Donna Haraway, 2016

BY DESIGN OR BY DISASTER – CONFERENCE The conference series of the University of Bolzano, Department of Social Design, is a platform for projects that reshape social coexistence through research, experimentation and practice. With the motto ‘By Design or by Disaster’, the theories and ideas of philosopher Donna Haraway form the basis of the conference. Conference Website: designdisaster.unibz.it

CO-AUTHOR The visual essay ‘Building Cultural Landscapes in Rural Areas - Lessons from the Land in Sicht Project’ was co-authored with our project partner Vanessa Graf-Müller, who also designed the illustrations for the text. Publication Download: String Figures – Transforming Together
LAND IN SICHT – FORMAT Get more information of the project ‚Land in Sicht‘ and our activities here: www.landinsicht-format.de

What role does social justice play in relation to sustainability and consumer behaviour?
What opportunities lie in improving economic and social relations between urban and rural areas?
How can sustainable consumption be achieved in times of crisis and increasing polarisation?

INVITATION TO THE DISCUSSION ROUND 'BETWEEN OPPOSITES'
We would like to invite you to our panel discussion »BETWEEN opposites - Sustainable consumption and social participation« on Saturday 16 March 2024 from 6.00 to 7.30 pm. 
You are welcome to join us for networking afterwards. To book a hot meal, please follow the information below.
In the form of a fishbowl discussion, our talk guests will provide initial impetus and invite you to join in the discussion:

projects.title: Flatterweg
projects.subtitle: Interim use on the former racecourse in Bremen

dynamic.text: INTERIM USE ON THE FORMER RACECOURSE IN BREMEN The more than 3,000 square meter racecourse site in Bremen is about to undergo an extensive conversion process, but at the beginning of 2020 the area will be opened up for interim use for the time being. The „Flatterweg“ is intended to invite citizens to explore the new urban space and help shape the site. The temporary pathway will also serve as a test run for the pathway connection planned by the city for the adjacent neighborhoods. What new references will this create in the urban space and what can be created along the route? We invite you to drop by.

dynamic.gallerycaption: Inauguration of the Flatterweg, Photos: Ricardo Nunes
captions: View over the racecourse
The „Neue Wolle“ design and production team
View of a flag
Inauguration party on the old tribune
Walk-through in the rain

dynamic.text:
DESIGN WORKSHOP, PRODUCTION AND ASSEMBLY

The women's creative laboratory „Neue Wolle“ from Blumenthal/ Bremen North designed and produced the flags for the „Flatterweg“. The cornerstone for this was a design workshop conceived by us at the beginning of the cooperation. Using a simple combination principle of graphic modules, a large number of flag designs were created, which were further varied during the sewing process. With 50 of these unique pieces, flags were erected on the site, marking around 500 meters of path.

captions: Paper modules for developing the designs
View into the workshop of „Neue Wolle“ in Bremen, Blumenthal
After designing, the fabric modules are sewn together.
Setting up on site
Setting up on site
After one day, all the flags are up.

dynamic.text: TOOLKIT FOR PARTICIPATION PROCESSES As part of a day of action, we set up five participation stations along the path where citizens could share their thoughts and ideas on the reuse of the site in so-called „Flatterheften“. We will then summarize the completed booklets and pass them on to political decision-makers. The Flatterweg provides access to political participation for young and old and directly on the site. What are the wishes and ideas of the participants? A look into the Flatterheft and the ideas and wishes of the participants can be found here (in German): Summary of the Flatterheft Here is an impression of the action day on site: buten un binnen reports

captions: Five groups of tables for participation line the „Flatterweg“ on the day of action.
The „Flatterheft“ is a playful way to take part in a survey of the site.

dynamic.text:
„The common desire was [to] simplify accessibility to urban development processes through flexible design.“
– Julian Essig: Die Schaffung von Sehnsuchtsorten durch Zwischennutzung; Hochschule Osnabrück 2022

The flag system could now be used to implement and test further pathways on the racecourse site, but also in other places, together with users. We are interested in alternative ways for people to participate in urban development. Participation with the help of design can produce the most diverse forms of solutions. We are open to find new challenges!

PROJECT PARTNER Under the name „Flatter-Crew“ we developed the concept for the „Flatterweg“ togehter with the designer Christof Mühe. We are united by an interdisciplinary design approach, with which we position ourselves at the interface of all participants - communicating, moderating, connecting. „Neue Wolle – Frauenkreativlabor“ is a project of Quartier gGmbH. It is aimed in particular at migrant women and single parents who dare to take their first steps into society and the world of work by learning, experimenting and designing together around wool and other textiles under artistic guidance. More information on the projects of the working group is available here: www.quartier-bremen.de/category/neue-wolle

dynamic.gallerycaption: The project was funded within the framework of the „Galop de Porc“ initiative.

dynamic.text: Why don't young creatives want to live and work in the countryside? Is there a lack of access or interest in creative and artistic services in rural areas?

PROJECT WEEK IN THE ALLGÄU Based on these questions, we initiated 'Land in Sicht' together with Vanessa Müller (Atelier Brieftaube, Ottobeuren). The project aims to promote an individual exchange between young creatives and rural communities. The common vision is to discover and open up new working and living spaces for creative people within rural structures. Both on the part of cultural creators and on the part of rural societies, a stronger understanding of each other's needs is to be gained.

In a first project week in autumn 2019, 13 young creatives from the fields of painting, photography, performance, design, fashion and music come together in the municipality of Ottobeuren in the Allgäu (population 8,381). They work as artists and designers in different urban contexts in the cultural and creative field. During this workshop week, they will transfer their working methods to the rural context and engage with its cultural infrastructure, especially the local museum for contemporary art. Through individual projects and joint workshops, they will explore the place of Ottobeuren and the potentials, particularities and challenges of rural areas as creative workplaces.

dynamic.gallerycaption: Impressions from the project week,, Photos: Jakob Weber, Sara Förster, Luisa Recker
captions: Arrival of the project participants
Ottobeuren, idyllically situated in Unterallgäu
Roger Fähndrich prepares a concert stage in the museum
In the kick-off workshop, potentials and challenges of rural life are collected
Christian Arnold (Käsundso) introduces the external participants to Swabian spaetzle culture
Photo shoot on the market square
The market square of Ottobeuren
Findings on ebay for the exhibition equipment

dynamic.text: As a result of the individual confrontation, 18 works were created. Using different themes and genres, they thematise the personal impressions and insights gained from a week of artistic work in a rural community. Following the project week, the works will be presented to the local public in a group exhibition in the foyer of the Museum of Contemporary Art - Diether Kunerth.The personal insights and assessments will be compiled, analysed and evaluated in a project documentation.

dynamic.gallerycaption: Impressions of the final exhibition, Photos: Jakob Weber

Vernissage

dynamic.text: We are currently working on another run of Land in Sight and improving our format. Are you interested in the project and do you have suggestions for us? Are you a cultural worker who lives and works in a rural region and would like to expand the cultural life here? You have had enough of a taste of the countryside and need a breath of fresh air? You are missing (more) creative minds in the surrounding area to realise a project with you? Then get in touch with us! For more information, you can download the final report here: Report ‚Land in Sicht‘

PROJECT PARTNER Vanessa Müller has created the 'Atelier Brieftaube' in Ottobeuren, a gem of the German cultural scene in the south of Germany, revitalising the young creative scene in rural areas. Vanessa works as a multimedia designer in Munich and Ottobeuren. Are you also looking for design partners in the south? Here are some insights into Vanessa's work: www.atelierbrieftau.be

FUNDING PARTNERS
The project was funded under the auspices of ‚Unternehmerfrauen im Handwerk Memmingen-Mindelheim‘, by ‚Unterallgäu aktiv/Europäischen Landwirtschaftsfonds für die Entwicklung des ländlichen Raumes‘ and by the municipality of Ottobeuren
